data.title: Communication, Niklas Luhmann, and the Fragmentation Debate in International Law
data.meta_description: This chapter offers a critical examination of Niklas Luhmann’s “systems” approach for our understanding of law. Although law has been traditionally understood as a system of rules or norms, Luhmann’s emphasis on autopoiesis and on...

Tamanaha espouses a “nonessential legal pluralism” that he contrasts with Teubner’s approach. While he considers law to be “whatever people identify and treat to their practices as law”——basically opting for a “folk” version of law——but then wants to move to “second level constructs” that help us identify phenomena to which the label “law” has been conventionally attached. Of course this is the $10,000 question that legal pluralists have not satisfactorily answered, despite a turn from a largely anthropological analysis of law to perspective informed by general jurisprudence. See Brian Tamanaha, A General Jurisprudence of Law and Society(Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2001), 194–195.
